name: RAG Retrieval Quality Evaluation
description: Test cases for evaluating retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) pipeline performance, measuring document retrieval quality and answer accuracy for student-athlete knowledge base queries

input.query: What are the GPA requirements for freshman NCAA eligibility?

retrievedDocuments.title: NCAA Division I Initial Eligibility Standards
retrievedDocuments.reason: Directly addresses freshman eligibility GPA requirements

retrievedDocuments.title: NCAA Sliding Scale for GPA and Test Scores
retrievedDocuments.reason: Explains how GPA requirements vary with test scores

retrievedDocuments.title: NCAA Core Course Requirements
retrievedDocuments.reason: Explains which courses count toward core GPA calculation

expected.answer: NCAA Division I requires incoming freshmen to have a minimum 2.3 GPA in 16 core courses to be eligible. However, the exact GPA requirement depends on your standardized test scores through the sliding scale. Students with higher GPAs (up to 3.55) can qualify with lower test scores, and vice versa.

input.query: How do I schedule a tutoring session?

retrievedDocuments.title: Academic Support Services: Tutoring Guide
retrievedDocuments.reason: Primary document explaining tutoring scheduling process

retrievedDocuments.title: Student Portal: How to Book Academic Support
retrievedDocuments.reason: Step-by-step instructions for using booking system

retrievedDocuments.title: Academic Support Services Overview
retrievedDocuments.reason: General overview of all support services including tutoring

expected.answer: You can schedule a tutoring session through the Student Portal. Log in, navigate to 'Academic Support,' select 'Tutoring,' choose your subject and preferred time, and book an available slot. You can also call the Academic Support office at (555) 123-4567 or email support@university.edu for assistance.

input.query: What happens if I change my major? Will it affect my eligibility?

retrievedDocuments.title: NCAA Progress Toward Degree Requirements
retrievedDocuments.reason: Explains how degree progress is calculated and major change impacts

retrievedDocuments.title: University Policy: Changing Your Major
retrievedDocuments.reason: Covers academic policies for major changes

retrievedDocuments.title: Eligibility FAQ: Degree Progress and Major Changes
retrievedDocuments.reason: Common questions about major changes and eligibility

retrievedDocuments.title: Academic Advising Guide: Choosing and Changing Majors
retrievedDocuments.reason: General guidance on major selection process

expected.answer: Changing your major can affect your eligibility, particularly regarding the 40-60-80 degree progress rule. Only courses that count toward your NEW major count toward degree progress percentages. However, all credits still count toward the 24-18 credit hour rule if they were degree-applicable when taken. You must meet with your academic advisor and compliance office before changing majors to understand the eligibility impact.

input.query: Can I take online courses during the season?

retrievedDocuments.title: NCAA Regulations: Online and Distance Education
retrievedDocuments.reason: Official NCAA rules on online course eligibility

retrievedDocuments.title: Online Course Approval Process for Student-Athletes
retrievedDocuments.reason: Step-by-step approval process for taking online courses

retrievedDocuments.title: Academic Flexibility Options for Athletes
retrievedDocuments.reason: Overview of flexible learning options including online courses

expected.answer: Yes, you can take online courses during the season and they count toward eligibility requirements. The courses must be offered by your institution or an approved provider, count toward your degree, and you still need to maintain 12+ credits per term. Get approval from your academic advisor before enrolling to ensure the courses meet NCAA requirements.

input.query: sliding scale test scores eligibility freshman

retrievedDocuments.title: NCAA Sliding Scale for GPA and Test Scores
retrievedDocuments.reason: Exact match for sliding scale query

retrievedDocuments.title: NCAA Division I Initial Eligibility Standards
retrievedDocuments.reason: Covers initial eligibility including test score requirements

retrievedDocuments.title: Initial Eligibility Calculator Guide
retrievedDocuments.reason: Tool for calculating eligibility with different GPA/test score combinations

expected.answer: The NCAA sliding scale allows different combinations of GPA and test scores for freshman eligibility. Higher GPAs (up to 3.55) allow lower test scores, and higher test scores allow lower GPAs (down to 2.3). For example, a 2.3 GPA requires a 1010 SAT or 86 ACT sum score, while a 3.55 GPA requires only 400 SAT or 37 ACT sum score.

input.query: What support is available if I'm struggling academically?

retrievedDocuments.title: Comprehensive Academic Support Services for Student-Athletes
retrievedDocuments.reason: Complete overview of support services for struggling students

retrievedDocuments.title: Academic Support Services: Tutoring Guide
retrievedDocuments.reason: Detailed tutoring options and scheduling

retrievedDocuments.title: Study Skills and Time Management Workshops
retrievedDocuments.reason: Workshops to improve academic skills

retrievedDocuments.title: Academic Mentoring Program for Student-Athletes
retrievedDocuments.reason: Long-term mentoring support

retrievedDocuments.title: Early Alert and Academic Intervention Services
retrievedDocuments.reason: Proactive intervention for at-risk students

expected.answer: Extensive support is available including: 1) Free one-on-one tutoring in all subjects, 2) Structured study halls with tutors available, 3) Academic mentoring for long-term support, 4) Study skills and time management workshops, 5) Supplemental instruction for difficult courses, and 6) Academic advisors who can help create a success plan. All services are free and designed specifically for student-athletes. Contact the Academic Support office to get started.

retrievedDocuments.title: NCAA Progress Toward Degree Requirements (40-60-80 Rule)
retrievedDocuments.reason: Primary document defining 40-60-80 rule

retrievedDocuments.title: Degree Progress Calculator and Tracking Guide
retrievedDocuments.reason: Tool for tracking progress toward degree percentages

retrievedDocuments.title: Continuing Eligibility Requirements for Student-Athletes
retrievedDocuments.reason: Overview of all continuing eligibility requirements including 40-60-80

expected.answer: The 40-60-80 rule requires student-athletes to complete specific percentages of their degree requirements: 40% by the end of second year, 60% by the end of third year, and 80% by the end of fourth year. This ensures you're making steady progress toward graduation, not just taking random classes. Only courses that count toward your declared major count toward these percentages.

input.query: Can my coach make me skip class for practice?

retrievedDocuments.title: NCAA Regulations: Class Attendance and Athletic Activities
retrievedDocuments.reason: Official NCAA rule prohibiting missing class for practice

retrievedDocuments.title: Student-Athlete Rights and Responsibilities
retrievedDocuments.reason: Outlines student rights regarding academics vs athletics

retrievedDocuments.title: How to Report NCAA Compliance Violations
retrievedDocuments.reason: Process for reporting improper coaching behavior

retrievedDocuments.title: University Class Attendance Policy for Student-Athletes
retrievedDocuments.reason: University policy protecting class attendance

expected.answer: No, NCAA rules strictly prohibit coaches from requiring you to miss class for practice or any athletically-related activity except competition and travel. Your education must come first. If this is happening, you should report it immediately to your Faculty Athletic Representative, Athletic Director, or Compliance Office. This is a serious NCAA violation, and you have protections against retaliation.

retrievedDocuments.title: NCAA Transfer Eligibility Requirements
retrievedDocuments.reason: Primary NCAA transfer eligibility rules

retrievedDocuments.title: Transfer Credit Evaluation Process
retrievedDocuments.reason: How transfer credits are evaluated and applied

retrievedDocuments.title: Transfer Student-Athlete Eligibility FAQ
retrievedDocuments.reason: Common transfer eligibility questions

retrievedDocuments.title: Degree Progress Calculation for Transfer Students
retrievedDocuments.reason: How transfer credits count toward 40-60-80 rule

expected.answer: Transfer credits count toward your credit hour requirements (24-18 rule) if they're accepted by your new institution and were degree-applicable at your previous school. However, transfer grades typically don't count toward your GPA at the new school, though NCAA may consider cumulative GPA from all institutions for eligibility. For the 40-60-80 degree progress rule, only credits that apply to your current degree program count. Work with both the Registrar's Office and Compliance Office to understand exactly how your transfer credits affect eligibility.

retrievedDocuments.title: FERPA: Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act Overview
retrievedDocuments.reason: Comprehensive FERPA overview

retrievedDocuments.title: FERPA Privacy Rights for Student-Athletes
retrievedDocuments.reason: FERPA specifically for student-athletes

retrievedDocuments.title: University Privacy Policies and Student Rights
retrievedDocuments.reason: General privacy policies including FERPA

expected.answer: FERPA (Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act) is a federal law that protects the privacy of your educational records. It controls who can access your grades, transcripts, and academic information. Generally, the university cannot share your academic information with anyone (including your parents, coaches, or team staff) without your written consent, unless you've signed a FERPA waiver. You have the right to review your educational records and request corrections if needed.

retrievedDocuments.title: NCAA Redshirt Eligibility Rules
retrievedDocuments.reason: Comprehensive redshirt eligibility rules

retrievedDocuments.title: Academic Redshirt Requirements and Implications
retrievedDocuments.reason: Academic redshirt specific information

retrievedDocuments.title: Managing Your Five-Year Eligibility Clock
retrievedDocuments.reason: How redshirt impacts 5-year eligibility clock

expected.answer: A redshirt season allows you to practice with the team but not compete, preserving a year of athletic eligibility. You still use one year of your five-year eligibility clock, but you keep all four years of competition. Academically, you must still maintain full-time enrollment (12+ credits), make satisfactory progress (24-18 rule), and meet all academic eligibility requirements during a redshirt year. An academic redshirt is different - it's for freshmen who didn't meet initial eligibility standards and can't practice or compete their first year.

input.query: summer courses count toward eligibility requirements?

retrievedDocuments.title: NCAA Rules for Summer Term Coursework
retrievedDocuments.reason: Official NCAA summer course eligibility rules

retrievedDocuments.title: Summer Session Planning Guide for Student-Athletes
retrievedDocuments.reason: Practical guide for summer course planning

retrievedDocuments.title: How Summer Credits Count Toward Degree Progress
retrievedDocuments.reason: Summer credit application to 40-60-80 rule

expected.answer: Yes, summer courses count toward eligibility requirements. Credits earned in summer count toward your cumulative total and the 40-60-80 degree progress rule if they're degree-applicable. However, for the 24-credit requirement before each season, only credits from the previous academic year (fall/spring) count - summer credits don't count toward the 24. Summer is a great opportunity to catch up on credits or boost your GPA. Get approval from your academic advisor before enrolling.

retrievedDocuments.title: Academic Mentoring Program for Student-Athletes
retrievedDocuments.reason: Mentoring for personalized study skills support

retrievedDocuments.title: Learning Styles Assessment and Resources
retrievedDocuments.reason: Understanding your learning style for better studying

expected.answer: We offer free study skills workshops covering time management, note-taking, test preparation, and balancing athletics with academics. You can also work one-on-one with an academic mentor who will help you develop personalized study strategies. Consider taking a learning styles assessment to understand how you learn best. Many student-athletes benefit from our study hall program where you can study with tutors available. Contact Academic Support to schedule a workshop or mentor.

input.query: withdrawal from course eligibility impact drop class

retrievedDocuments.title: Course Withdrawal Policy for Student-Athletes
retrievedDocuments.reason: Specific policy on withdrawals and eligibility impact

retrievedDocuments.title: NCAA Credit Requirements: How Withdrawals Affect Eligibility
retrievedDocuments.reason: NCAA rules on withdrawn courses and eligibility

retrievedDocuments.title: Consulting Your Advisor Before Withdrawing from Courses
retrievedDocuments.reason: Process for withdrawal approval

retrievedDocuments.title: How Withdrawn Courses Affect Degree Progress
retrievedDocuments.reason: Impact of withdrawals on 40-60-80 rule

expected.answer: Withdrawing from a course can affect your eligibility in several ways: 1) It may drop you below the 12-credit full-time minimum, 2) Withdrawn credits don't count toward your 24-credit or 18-credit requirements, 3) They don't count toward degree progress (40-60-80 rule). You MUST get approval from your academic advisor AND compliance office before withdrawing from any course. Strategically timed withdrawals can sometimes help protect your GPA, but they must be carefully planned to maintain eligibility.
